channel.title: Gatsby Advanced Starter
channel.description: A GatsbyJS stater with Advanced design in mind.
channel.author: Advanced User

item.title: Labs Week IV
item.description: Individual Accomplishments this Week Github handle: This week was the best for teamwork so far. We made great strides over the last four…
item.dc:creator: Advanced User
item.content:encoded:
Individual Accomplishments this Week

Github handle: jcuffe

This week was the best for teamwork so far. We made great strides over the last four days, and greatly improved the appeal of our product.

Tasks Pulled

Front End

  • Look and Feel

    • Document List look and feel
    • Refactors sidebar styles and markup
    • Adds color to reported tones, with width varying by strength
    • EmailCreate control organization
    • Responsive breakpoints
    • Modifies breakpoints for analysis to ensure order consistency on phone

Back End

  • Database

    • Refactors database logic to prevent Postgres errors on deploy
    • Refactors middleware to squash production bug

Detailed Analysis

This week had a unique lack of variety in the tasks I pulled. While I worked on every component across the project, I had the same goal in each file. Most of my effort was spent in the user list of documents, ensuring that it looked good across all breakpoints. Looking at it now, I think our mobile view looks even better than the desktop!

The editor component also received a major overhaul, using bootstrap's layout tricks to place the analysis content above the editor on the small screen. I also corralled the controls into a single group, and made sure they looked consistent across breakpoints.

The last area I concentrated on styling was the new user profile page. I wanted a central column near which the user's profile information could be aligned, which I achieved using fixed-width spans.

I'm very happy with how our site looks and feels now!

Milestone Reflections

The objective this week was completely focused on the front-end, and specifically the user's experience as they navigated the site. In order to be successful this week, we realized that we had to create a uniform experience for the user, where nothing was out of place, and every action available to the user was intuitively obvious. While it may have been the result of pointed prompting, I feel that our team was much more productive in our meetings, where we focused on nailing down choices that would be visible throughout our app, such as the card-based layout.

item.title: Labs Week III
item.description: Individual Accomplishments this Week Github handle: This week, we had a new team member to integrate with the group, so I split my time…
item.dc:creator: Advanced User
item.content:encoded:
Individual Accomplishments this Week

Github handle: jcuffe

This week, we had a new team member to integrate with the group, so I split my time between implementing features and re-implementing broken features.

Tasks Pulled

Front End

  • Logout

    • Implements logout functionality on client and server.

  • Functionality

    • Implements version navigation and highlighting
    • Implements sentence-level highlighting of Watson analysis

  • Styles

    • Responsive Documents list
    • Responsive Email create component

Back End

  • Database

    • Provides last updated time for documents in list view
    • Fixes analysis persistence bug by use of JSON

Detailed Analysis

The task I was most satisfied to complete this week was the responsive redesign of the DocumentList component. My original mockup was awful, without even the decency to wrap across multiple lines:

Luckily, I spotted some clean, appealing markup in a file Fred was working on, and decided that Reactstrap was going to get me out of this mess. I clobbered the entirety of the markup I had built to this point, and rewrote the layout using Reactstrap components.

While the look of the component could still use a little polish, I'm happy to say that the main views of our app are fully responsive, as well as being simple and intuitive to use.

Milestone Reflections

This week focused on bringing together our various components, and doing our best to get them on a single theme. Our team had a unique circumstance this week, with a member of a dying team joining ours. While this caused a significant portion of time to be spent on catching the new teammate up, and rewriting code which was based off of incomplete assumptions, I still believe that the team made significant accomplishments this week. Having said that, I am already longing for an environment where tasks are allocated by an individual with the explicit role of integrating disparate workflows. I have found it very difficult to hold hands and code at the same time - speech-to-text, perhaps?

item.title: Labs Week II
item.description: Individual Accomplishments this Week Github handle: This week, I decided to take a more reactive role and choose my tasks based on what the…
item.dc:creator: Advanced User
item.content:encoded:
Individual Accomplishments this Week

Github handle: jcuffe

This week, I decided to take a more reactive role and choose my tasks based on what the rest of the team was focusing on. I spent most of my time on the communication between the client and server, implementing persistence for data entered by the user. I also finalized the OAuth implementation on deployment.

Tasks Pulled

Front End

  • Login flow

    • Finalize login flow

  • Functionality

    • Implements email fetching on client side
    • Implements version persistence from client to server

Back End

  • Testing

    • Backend login testing

  • Database

    • Adds versions table to database schema

  • Routing

    • Emails and versions routers
    • Subscriptions schema and router

Detailed Analysis

This week's trickiest bit was on the client side, implementing the persistence of versions. Due to the normalization of our schema, our email editing component on the client side is responsible for sending data about two different schemas to the back end. I decided to handle this one the server side, and have the client send up all the relevant data in a single request. This choice has the benefit of keeping the client/server interaction to a single round-trip, and the cost of increasing the complexity of the server endpoint was minimal:

The most difficult part of this was ensuring that references to the user and email ids were available at the time a version creation attempt was made. Prior to resolving this, I ran into many sqlite errors, resulting from an attempted version insertion without the required foreign key data.

In the end, I got it working smoothly, and I'm looking forward to polishing up the look and feel!

Milestone Reflections

This week was definitely more challenging than the last. The task of integrating the various bodies of code we had each created brought many challenges. Luckily, the hazards were mitigated by our use of Trello, allowing me to see what my teammates were working on and choose something that wouldn't cause conflicts come merge time. Still, I have had to stay vigilant and read each of my teammates' pull requests in full, to ensure that I was abreast of any new assumptions encoded in the software and aware of any pitfalls on the road ahead.

The highlight of the week, in this vein, was finding a corsforstripe.js in the same directory as the cors.js configuration I had already written. As frustrating as it can be to stay vigilant of these issues, it is encouraging to know that other developers in the job pool are making mistakes that I've prevented myself from making via my process.

item.title: Labs Week I
item.description: Individual Accomplishments this Week Github handle: This week, I placed my self in the role of prototyping the core features of our app. I…
item.dc:creator: Advanced User
item.content:encoded:
Individual Accomplishments this Week

Github handle: jcuffe

This week, I placed my self in the role of prototyping the core features of our app. I had a clear vision of how I wanted to organize the codebase, so I made sure to jump in and start working in the repository immediately. In addition to scaffolding the codebase, I also handled the deployment of our app to Heroku and Netlify. I ran into difficulty during the configuration of these services, but was able to resolve the issues with little trouble after some research and contacting the appropriate people. Additionally, I initialized an account with Auth0 for our app, which will handle user authentication. This week was relatively code-light, and my primary tools were my browser and Google.

Tasks Pulled

Back End

  • Heroku Deploy

    • Github - Configures project for Heroku deployment of back end server
    • Trello - Deploy server to Heroku

  • Netlify Deploy

    • Github - Modifies post-install script to avoid errors caused by the --prefix flag
    • Trello - Deploy client to netlify

  • OAuth Implementation

    • Github - Implements back-end OAuth authentication flow
    • Trello - Implement User Authentication with OAuth

  • Database Middleware

    • Github - Implements middleware to populate current user's data on the session.
    • Trello - Create a middleware that attaches a User from the db to the session

Detailed Analysis

My most challenging task this week was the implementation of OAuth on the back end. This feature required the cooperation of several libraries and services, particularly passport and express-session. I started out in familiar territory, configuring our express app to use an Auth0 passport strategy.

I encountered difficulties while testing the functionality in the production environment, due to behavior differences in cookie handling between development and production environments. By researching the configuration options provided for each library, I was able to finalize a solution that properly serves cookies in both development and production.

I was happy to end up with an implementation that "just worked" for our users, and which didn't cause bloat in our codebase. I feel like our authentication code is about as lean as it can get!

Milestone Reflections

The experience of forming a team this week was alright to me. I helped the team by supporting tech and design choices that would lead to the least overhead in the long run. Having been a PM for the previous labs, I had identified many points on which teams had gotten stuck for multiple days. I decided that these common problems were the biggest threat to our supply of developer hours, and championed choices that would allow us to avoid them.

As a result of this, I realize that I treated some choices as foregone conclusions, and may have robbed my teammates of the opportunity to discuss them. Upon reflection, I consider this a consequence of our loosely-knit group structure. In the absence of clear directions from a leader, I feel that group direction will be driven by the most proactive members of the group. I have noticed that this can cause hard feelings in less assertive or active members, and am interested in learning to circumvent these pitfalls while still retaining my effectiveness.

item.title: Big Test
item.description: NOTE: This "post" is based on Markdown Cheatsheet and is meant to test styling of Markdown generated documents. This is intended as a…
item.dc:creator: Advanced User
item.content:encoded:
NOTE: This "post" is based on Markdown Cheatsheet and is meant to test styling of Markdown generated documents.

This is intended as a quick reference and showcase. For more complete info, see John Gruber's original spec and the Github-flavored Markdown info page.

This cheatsheet is specifically Markdown Here's version of Github-flavored Markdown. This differs slightly in styling and syntax from what Github uses, so what you see below might vary a little from what you get in a Markdown Here email, but it should be pretty close.

You can play around with Markdown on our live demo page.

(If you're not a Markdown Here user, check out the Markdown Cheatsheet that is not specific to MDH. But, really, you should also use Markdown Here, because it's awesome. http://markdown-here.com)

Table of Contents

Headers Emphasis Lists Links Images Code and Syntax Highlighting Tables Blockquotes Inline HTML Horizontal Rule Line Breaks YouTube Videos

Headers

# H1
## H2
### H3
#### H4
##### H5
###### H6

Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style:

Alt-H1
======

Alt-H2
------

H1

H2

H3

H4

H5
H6

Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style:

Alt-H1

Alt-H2

Emphasis

Emphasis, aka italics, with *asterisks* or _underscores_.

Strong emphasis, aka bold, with **asterisks** or __underscores__.

Combined emphasis with **asterisks and _underscores_**.

Strikethrough uses two tildes. ~~Scratch this.~~

Emphasis, aka italics, with asterisks or underscores.

Strong emphasis, aka bold, with asterisks or underscores.

Combined emphasis with asterisks and underscores.

Strikethrough uses two tildes. Scratch this.

Lists

1. First ordered list item
2. Another item
  * Unordered sub-list.
1. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number
  1. Ordered sub-list
4. And another item.

   Some text that should be aligned with the above item.

* Unordered list can use asterisks
- Or minuses
+ Or pluses

  1. First ordered list item

  2. Another item

    • Unordered sub-list.

  3. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number

    1. Ordered sub-list

  4. And another item.

    Some text that should be aligned with the above item.

  5. Unordered list can use asterisks

  6. Or minuses

  7. Or pluses

Links

There are two ways to create links.

[I'm an inline-style link](https://www.google.com)

[I'm a reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]

[You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions][1]

Or leave it empty and use the [link text itself]

URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links.
http://www.example.com or <http://www.example.com> and sometimes
example.com (but not on Github, for example).

Some text to show that the reference links can follow later.

[arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.mozilla.org
[1]: http://slashdot.org
[link text itself]: http://www.reddit.com

I'm an inline-style link

I'm a reference-style link

You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions

Or leave it empty and use the link text itself

URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or http://www.example.com and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, for example).

Some text to show that the reference links can follow later.

Images

Here's our logo (hover to see the title text):

Inline-style:
![alt text](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 1")

Reference-style:
![alt text][logo]

[logo]: https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 2"

Here's our logo (hover to see the title text):

Inline-style:

Reference-style:

Code and Syntax Highlighting

Code blocks are part of the Markdown spec, but syntax highlighting isn't. However, many renderers -- like Github's and Markdown Here -- support syntax highlighting. Markdown Here supports highlighting for dozens of languages (and not-really-languages, like diffs and HTTP headers); to see the complete list, and how to write the language names, see the highlight.js demo page.

Inline `code` has `back-ticks around` it.

Inline code has back-ticks around it.

Blocks of code are either fenced by lines with three back-ticks `, or are indented with four spaces. I recommend only using the fenced code blocks -- they're easier and only they support syntax highlighting.

```javascript
var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting";
alert(s);
```

```python
s = "Python syntax highlighting"
print s
```

```
No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting.
But let's throw in a <b>tag</b>.
```

var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting";
alert(s);
s = "Python syntax highlighting"
print s
No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting in Markdown Here (varies on Github).
But let's throw in a <b>tag</b>.

Again, to see what languages are available for highlighting, and how to write those language names, see the highlight.js demo page.

Tables

Tables aren't part of the core Markdown spec, but they are part of GFM and Markdown Here supports them. They are an easy way of adding tables to your email -- a task that would otherwise require copy-pasting from another application.

Colons can be used to align columns.

| Tables        | Are           | Cool  |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|
| col 3 is      | right-aligned | $1600 |
| col 2 is      | centered      |   $12 |
| zebra stripes | are neat      |    $1 |

The outer pipes (|) are optional, and you don't need to make the raw Markdown line up prettily. You can also use inline Markdown.

Markdown | Less | Pretty
--- | --- | ---
*Still* | `renders` | **nicely**
1 | 2 | 3

Colons can be used to align columns.

Tables Are Cool
col 3 is right-aligned $1600
col 2 is centered $12
zebra stripes are neat $1

The outer pipes (|) are optional, and you don't need to make the raw Markdown line up prettily. You can also use inline Markdown.

Markdown Less Pretty
Still renders nicely
1 2 3

Blockquotes

> Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text.
> This line is part of the same quote.

Quote break.

> This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can *put* **Markdown** into a blockquote.

Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text. This line is part of the same quote.

Quote break.

This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can put Markdown into a blockquote.

Inline HTML

You can also use raw HTML in your Markdown, and it'll mostly work pretty well.

<dl>
  <dt>Definition list</dt>
  <dd>Is something people use sometimes.</dd>

  <dt>Markdown in HTML</dt>
  <dd>Does *not* work **very** well. Use HTML <em>tags</em>.</dd>
</dl>
Definition list
Is something people use sometimes.
Markdown in HTML
Does *not* work **very** well. Use HTML tags.

Horizontal Rule

Three or more...

---

Hyphens

***

Asterisks

___

Underscores

Three or more...

Hyphens

Asterisks

Underscores

Line Breaks

My basic recommendation for learning how line breaks work is to experiment and discover -- hit <Enter> once (i.e., insert one newline), then hit it twice (i.e., insert two newlines), see what happens. You'll soon learn to get what you want. "Markdown Toggle" is your friend.

Here are some things to try out:

Here's a line for us to start with.

This line is separated from the one above by two newlines, so it will be a *separate paragraph*.

This line is also a separate paragraph, but...
This line is only separated by a single newline, so it's a separate line in the *same paragraph*.

Here's a line for us to start with.

This line is separated from the one above by two newlines, so it will be a separate paragraph.

This line is also begins a separate paragraph, but... This line is only separated by a single newline, so it's a separate line in the same paragraph.

(Technical note: Markdown Here uses GFM line breaks, so there's no need to use MD's two-space line breaks.)

YouTube Videos

They can't be added directly but you can add an image with a link to the video like this:

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=8AkLfYOgIrE
" target="_blank"><img src="http://img.youtube.com/vi/8AkLfYOgIrE/0.jpg"
alt="IMAGE ALT TEXT HERE" width="240" height="180" border="10" /></a>

Or, in pure Markdown, but losing the image sizing and border:

[![IMAGE ALT TEXT HERE](http://img.youtube.com/vi/YOUTUBE_VIDEO_ID_HERE/0.jpg)](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YOUTUBE_VIDEO_ID_HERE)
